channel.title: Comments on: SQL Server Stored Procedure with nvarchar parameter
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Rex
item.dc:creator: Rex
item.description: The info about default lengths (or maximum lengths) is interesting and will probably come in handy during future debugging. Though I would consider refining this article in order to better differentiate variable length data types varchar and nvarchar (string equivalents) and their "maximum size" or “maximum length” (perhaps in bold at the beginning of the article) versus fixed length data types (character? data types) which really aren't strings. The big advancement brought about by strings is that you avoid fixing a length so that you don't have to worry so much about padded blanks and/or allocating a fixed memory size for the maximum you might ever need. Sorry so picky…
item.content:encoded: The info about default lengths (or maximum lengths) is interesting and will probably come in handy during future debugging. Though I would consider refining this article in order to better differentiate variable length data types varchar and nvarchar (string equivalents) and their “maximum size” or “maximum length” (perhaps in bold at the beginning of the article) versus fixed length data types (character? data types) which really aren’t strings. The big advancement brought about by strings is that you avoid fixing a length so that you don’t have to worry so much about padded blanks and/or allocating a fixed memory size for the maximum you might ever need. Sorry so picky…

item.title: By: Jan Novak
item.dc:creator: Jan Novak
item.content:encoded:
It is great article. But I think one thing is not correct.

Instead of:
EXEC TestParameterLength ‘Hello World’

we should use
EXEC TestParameterLength N’Hello World’

It is because the datatype is nvarchar and not varchar.

item.title: By: sqlsister
item.dc:creator: sqlsister
item.description: It's the little sneaky things like this that trip people up. Good tip.
item.content:encoded: It’s the little sneaky things like this that trip people up. Good tip.

item.title: By: David Forck (thirster42)
item.dc:creator: David Forck (thirster42)
item.description: I always specify a size for any 'string' variable/parameter so i've never ran into this problem
item.content:encoded: I always specify a size for any ‘string’ variable/parameter so i’ve never ran into this problem

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: I said the same as you, I wish convert would also be 1 character like a param
item.content:encoded: I said the same as you, I wish convert would also be 1 character like a param

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.content:encoded:
I’m not sure what you mean by this.

In the post I say that convert defaults to 30 characters instead of 1 character when declaring it as a parameter or local variable. This happens for char, nchar, varchar, and nvarchar.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
However when you do something like

select convert(varchar,getdate())

then the length is 30 characters for some strange reason
